header: Joab Sends a Wise Woman to David

verse: Joab son of Zeruiah knew that ·King David missed Absalom very much [David’s heart longed for/mind was on Absalom].

So Joab sent messengers to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He said to her, “Pretend ·to be very sad [you are in mourning]. Put on ·funeral [mourning] clothes and don’t put ·lotion [perfume; anointing oil] on yourself. Act like a woman who has been ·crying [mourning] many days for someone who died.
Then go to the king and say these words.” Then Joab ·told her what to say [put the words in her mouth].
·So [When…] the woman from Tekoa spoke to the king. She bowed facedown on the ground ·to show respect [and prostrated herself] and said, “My king, help me!”
King David asked her, “What is ·the matter [troubling you]?”
I had two sons. They were out in the field fighting, and no one was there to ·stop [separate] them. So one ·son [struck and] killed the other son.

Now ·all the family group [the whole family/clan] ·is [has risen] against me. They said to me, ‘·Bring [Hand over; Give up] the son who ·killed [struck] his brother so we may ·kill [execute] him for ·killing [murdering; taking the life of] his brother. That way we will ·also get rid of the one who would receive what belonged to his father [destroy the heir as well; so he doesn’t profit from his crime].’ ·My son is like the last spark of a fire. He is all [They want to extinguish/quench the only coal/ember] I have left. ·If they kill him, my [My] husband’s name and ·property [or family; descendents; remnant] will be gone from the ·earth [face of the earth].”
Then the king said to the woman, “Go home. I will ·take care of this for [give orders concerning] you.”
The woman of Tekoa said to him, “Let the ·blame [guilt] be on me and my father’s family. My ·master and [lord the] king, you and your throne are ·innocent [guiltless].”
King David said, “Bring me anyone who ·says anything bad to [threatens; criticizes] you. Then he won’t ·bother [touch] you again.”

The woman said, “Please ·promise in the name of [swear by; remember; keep in mind] the Lord your God. Then ·my relative who has the duty of punishing a murderer [my near-relative; the avenger of blood; a relative obligated to execute the murderer; Num. 35:12, 19–21] won’t ·add to [continue] the destruction by killing my son.”
The woman said, “Let me say something to you, my ·master and [lord the] king.”

Then the woman said, “Why have you ·decided this way against [acted/planned to the harm/detriment of] the people of God? When you ·judge [decide; speak] this way, you ·show that you are guilty [convict yourself] for not bringing back your son who was ·forced to leave home [banished].

We will all die someday. We’re like water spilled on the ground; no one can ·gather it back [collect it together]. But God doesn’t ·take away [discard] life. Instead, he plans ways that ·those who have been sent away will not have to stay away from him [will bring back/home the banished]!

My ·master and [lord the] king, I came to say this to you because the people have ·made me afraid [threatened/intimidated me]! I thought, ‘Let me talk to the king. Maybe he will ·do [grant] what I ask.

Maybe he will listen. Perhaps he will ·save [rescue; deliver] me from ·those who want to keep both me and my son from getting what God gave us [the hand of the man who would cut me and my son from God’s inheritance/heritage].’

“Now I say, ‘May the words of my ·master [lord] the king give me ·rest [comfort; peace]. Like an angel of God, you ·know [discern; understand] what is good and what is ·bad [evil]. May the Lord your God be with you!’”
Then King David said, “Do not ·hide [evade] the truth. Answer me one question.”
The king said, “·Did Joab tell you to say [Is Joab’s hand with you in] all these things?”
Joab did it ·so you would see things differently [to change the look of things]. My ·master [lord], you are wise like an angel of God who knows ·everything that happens [all things] on earth.”
The king said to Joab, “Look, I ·will do what I promised [grant this request]. Bring back the young man Absalom.”

Joab bowed facedown on the ground [and prostrated himself] and blessed the king. Then he said, “Today I know ·you are pleased with me [I have found favor in your sight/eyes], because you have done what I asked.”
Then Joab got up and went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
But King David said, “Absalom must go to his own house. He may not ·come to see me [see my face].” So Absalom went to his own house and did not ·go to see the king [see the king’s face].
Absalom was greatly praised for his ·handsome appearance [beauty]. No man in Israel was as handsome as he. No ·blemish [flaw; defect] was on him from his head to his foot.
At the end of every year, Absalom would cut his hair, because it became too heavy. When he weighed it, it would weigh ·about five pounds by the royal measure [200 shekels by the king’s standard].
Absalom had three sons and one daughter. His daughter’s name was also Tamar, and she was a beautiful woman.
Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two full years without seeing ·King David [the king’s face].
Then Absalom sent for Joab so he could send him to the king [to intercede for him], but Joab would not come. Absalom sent a message a second time, but Joab still refused to come.
Then Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley growing there. Go burn it.” So Absalom’s servants set fire to Joab’s field.
Then Joab went to Absalom’s house and said to him, “Why did your servants burn my field?”

Absalom said to Joab, “I sent a message to you, asking you to come here. I wanted to send you to the king to ask him why ·he brought me home [I have come] from Geshur. It would have been better for me to stay there! Now let me see the ·king [king’s face]. If I have ·sinned [guilt/iniquity in me], he can put me to death!”
So Joab went to the king and told him Absalom’s words. Then the king called for Absalom. Absalom came and ·bowed facedown [prostrated himself] on the ground before the king, and the king kissed him.
